items.title: Trump declares fentanyl a 'weapon of mass destruction' with executive order
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday declaring fentanyl a weapon of mass destruction, a move that dramatically expands the U.S. government's authority to fight the synthetic opioid blamed for tens of thousands of American overdose deaths each year.

items.title: Quebec teachers say they’re targeted by violence, verbal abuse in schools
items.summary_auto: Teachers across the province are warning of increased violence directed toward them inside classrooms. A major teachers’ union released a survey documenting the trend and is reaching out to the province for help.

items.title: What we know about Nick Reiner, in custody following his parents' deaths
items.summary_auto: Nick struggled with drug addiction and homelessness from the time he was a teenager, and made a film in his 20s alongside his dad about a young man's struggles with addiction. Los Angeles Police said Monday that Nick was in custody related to their death and was being held without bail.

items.title: U.S. offers security guarantees to Kyiv, says Russia not opposed to Ukraine joining EU
items.summary_auto: The U.S. has agreed to provide unspecified security guarantees to Ukraine as part of a peace deal to end Russia's nearly four-year war, and more talks are likely this weekend, U.S. officials said Monday following the latest discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Berlin.

items.title: Family of Ontario man whose 2016 jail death sparked inquest still waiting for apology from province
Canadian Victoria Mboko named Women's Tennis Association top newcomer in 2025
items.summary_auto: Canadian tennis star Victoria Mboko has been named the WTA's newcomer of the year.

items.title: Canadian military intelligence operative accused of leaking secrets released from custody
items.summary_auto: A member of the Canadian military intelligence community accused of leaking sensitive information to a foreign entity has been released from military police custody. Master Warrant Officer Matthew Robar faces eight charges in connection with unspecified alleged incidents last year.

items.title: Ontario has no plans to sell off stored U.S. alcohol for charity, Ford says
items.summary_auto: Ontario Premier Doug Ford says his government has no plan to sell off a stockpile of American alcohol sitting in storage to benefit charities over the holiday season, for fear it could harm local producers.

items.title: Saskatoon teen admits to lighting classmate on fire in 2024
items.summary_auto: A Saskatoon teen is admitting she planned and executed a fiery assault on a classmate at Evan Hardy Collegiate in September 2024.

items.title: National home sales fell in November with housing activity in 'holding pattern,' says CREA
items.summary_auto: National home sales fell 10.7 per cent in November compared with the same month last year, as the Canadian Real Estate Association says activity has veered into a "holding pattern" heading into 2026.

items.title: Anti-Kremlin punk band Pussy Riot designated an extremist group by Russian court
items.summary_auto: The Russian anti-Kremlin feminist punk band and art collective known as Pussy Riot was designated an extremist organization by a Moscow court on Monday, banning its activities inside Russia as part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices.

items.title: Triumph of light over darkness: St. John's celebrates first night of Hanukkah
items.summary_auto: The parking lot outside of the Viking Building in St. John's was full for a chilly Sunday evening, but vehicles filed in for a menorah lighting ceremony to celebrate the first night of Hanukkah.

items.title: U.S. Army identifies 2 Iowa Guard members killed in weekend attack in Syria
items.summary_auto: The two Iowa National Guard members killed in a weekend attack in Syria that the U.S. military blamed on the Islamic State group were identified Monday and remembered as dedicated soldiers.

items.title: Scottie Scheffler named PGA Tour player of year for 4th straight time, joining Tiger Woods
items.summary_auto: Scottie Scheffler earned another comparison with Tiger Woods on Monday, joining him as the only players to win PGA Tour player of the year at least four times in a row.

items.title: One dead in collapse at K3 underground mine in Esterhazy, Sask., Mosaic says
items.summary_auto: According to a statement issued by the Mosaic Company, the incident happened at the K3 underground mine in Esterhazy, approximately 90 kilometres southeast of Yorkton, Sask.

items.title: 4 charged with plotting 'multiple' New Year's Eve bombing attacks in Southern California
items.summary_auto: Federal authorities said Monday that they foiled a plot to bomb multiple U.S. companies on New Year's Eve in Southern California, announcing the arrests of members of an extremist anti-capitalist and anti-government group.

items.title: Menorah lighting a chance for this Jewish community in Ontario to 'feel a togetherness'
items.summary_auto: Members of the Jewish community in Waterloo, Ont., celebrated the first night of Hanukkah on Sunday by lighting a massive five-metre-high menorah, taking time to also reflect on the fatal shooting at Bondi Beach in Australia.

items.title: Mariah Carey to perform at opening ceremony for Milano-Cortina Olympics
items.summary_auto: Mariah Carey is the first international star named to perform in the opening ceremony of the 2026 Winter Olympics on Feb. 6 at Milan’s San Siro stadium, according to the local organizing committee.

items.title: Flu blamed in deaths of 3 children in Ottawa area this month
More Canadians head to Mexico for winter getaways
Rob Reiner's son in custody in connection with his parents' killings
items.summary_auto: The son of filmmaker Rob Reiner was arrested on homicide charges after the actor-director and his wife were found dead in their Los Angeles home, a police official said Monday.

items.title: These are the victims killed and injured in the Bondi Beach attack
items.summary_auto: Among the 15 victims of a mass shooting at Australia's Bondi Beach during an event for the Jewish festival of Hanukkah on Sunday were a rabbi, a Holocaust survivor and a 10-year-old girl, according to interviews, officials and local media reports.

items.title: Why this North Vancouver club has produced 3 of the top young hockey stars
items.summary_auto: University of Minnesota defender Chloe Primerano, and NHLers Macklin Celebrini and Connor Bedard all played for the North Shore Winter Club in North Vancouver as kids. Now, they all hope to be in Italy for the Olympics this February.

items.title: 'Slop' is Merriam-Webster's word of the year for 2025
items.summary_auto: The word "slop" was first used to refer to soft mud in the 1700s, but has since evolved to mean of little value — especially when referring to online content of low quality that's made with artificial intelligence. Runners-up include "touch grass," "performative" and "6-7."

items.title: What we know about Ahmed al-Ahmed, the Bondi Beach bystander who disarmed gunman
items.summary_auto: The family of Ahmed al-Ahmed, a Syrian Muslim father of two who tackled one of the alleged attackers during the mass shooting on Sunday at Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, has spoken out, hailing their son as a "hero."

items.title: Canada's inflation rate stayed flat in November but grocery prices grew at fastest pace in nearly 2 years
items.summary_auto: Canada's annual inflation rate was unchanged at 2.2 per cent in November, Statistics Canada said on Monday.

items.title: Trump wildly claims Rob Reiner died of 'Trump derangement syndrome'
Law enforcement hunting for Brown University gunman go door-knocking to ask about video
items.summary_auto: Authorities knocked on doors Monday searching for any video there might be of the Brown University gunman, who could be seen in grainy footage walking away from the weekend attack that killed two students and wounded nine others.

items.title: Bed-building program gives back while teaching a trade
items.summary_auto: Oyate Tipi Cumini Yape, a Winnipeg-based furniture bank, has made 250 beds for people in need this year with help from volunteers, including teens who get to learn a new skill while helping others.

items.title: Ontario teen sets Guinness World record for stacking bottle caps using chopsticks
items.summary_auto: Ever tried to stack up bottle caps? Against those shaking odds, Daniel Joseph Ireneo has made a Guinness World Record for stacking 12 caps in 30 seconds using chopsticks on Aug. 13, just a couple of days before his 14th birthday.

items.title: Renters consider leaving N.L. after no-fault eviction ‘upheaved’ their lives
items.summary_auto: After moving to St. John's, N.L. from Ontario, a couple built a comfortable life in a two-bedroom apartment with their cat. Two years later a no-fault eviction forced them to start over.

items.title: A Stephenville doctor says the health-care system owes him $200K. Without it, he'll quit
items.summary_auto: Neil Patterson says he signed a contract with Newfoundland and Labrador Health Services with the promise of incentives and bonuses that never came to fruition.

items.title: Vacant upscale north Toronto homes should house low-income families, advocates say
items.summary_auto: A commercial real estate developer well known for his philanthropic work, along with a ratepayers group and a local refugee shelter, are floating a plan to transform 10 vacant houses in a tiny north Toronto neighbourhood into temporary homes for low-income families.

items.title: 'It was fully ignored': This woman's medical emergency in Ontario jail reflects broader health-care crisis
items.summary_auto: More than a third of complaints filed by prisoners in Ontario jails this year were health-related, as medical staffing dropped by nearly 50 per cent and inmate populations kept rising, a CBC data analysis shows. One former inmate suffered a septic wound and a miscarriage while incarcerated.

items.title: Liberal, NDP MPs to visit West Bank, connect with Palestinians
items.summary_auto: A group of five Liberal MPs and a lone NDP parliamentarian are planning to spend three days in Israel and the Occupied West Bank, at a time of heightened tensions between Ottawa and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
